content-body.text: Stocks did well on Monday, the 29 of August 2016, in the US, but went slightly lower in Europe and Asia. In the US, trading was invigorated by highly positive consumer reports for July. The data showed that consumer spending, most essential for the economic development of the country, has steadily been growing for the last four months. And even though the same reports simultaneously pointed to an increase in the personal savings rate indicative of the possible reduction of consumer spending in future, investors considered the consumption data to be a good beginning of the third quarter. The US stocks jumped led by banks and other financial companies. Banks appreciated on Monday in the wake of the Fed Reserve’s intention to introduce a rate rise in September. All big banks -- JPMorgan, Wells Fargo, Bank of America, and Goldman Sachs - gained. The US indices finished the trading day in the green. The Dow Jones industries rose 0.6%. The S&P advanced 0.5%. The NASDAQ edged 0.3% higher. The European indices fared worse than their American counterparts. The CAC declined 0.4%. The DAX lost as much. The SMI edged 0.2% down. The FTSE was closed for the Bank Holiday. The US dollar continued raising. Crude oil prices continued sinking, brought lower by Iraq’s intention to carry on pumping more oil.

The US dollar is still up against all its major counterparts – the euro, the pound, the Swiss franc, the Australian dollar, the Canadian dollar, and the yen. Its biggest gains are against the yen, because investors are preferring to rely now more on the dollar than on the yen.

Because Federal Reserve Chairwoman, Professor Janet Yellen, implied that rates would be increased as early as in September, metals came under pressure. Overall, gold shed 2.1% in July, thereby changing its trajectory that had moved upward until May. Even though precious metals were higher on the early Tuesday than during the previous night, they were still in the red. Gold was 0.18% down to reach US$1,320.96. Silver shed 0.37% to US$18.79. Platinum edged 0.30% lower to US$1,073.98. Oil is trading slightly higher than last week, when it went even dipper, once investors realised that Saudi Arabia had self-servingly talked up oil prices and Iran would not budge and would not stop pumping. Brent Crude is up 0.55%, trading at $49.53 per barrel. WTI Crude added 0.64% to reach US47.28. Copper retreated 0.14% to US$2.07.

US Market. Herbalife’s largest shareholder denied that he had ever intended to sell his stocks. After he had bought 2.3 million shares, the company advanced 4.52%. Micron Technology also soared, adding 2.42% on Tuesday morning. Allegheny Technologies had a jump of 11.11%.

European Market. Unlike banks in the US, banks in Europe were planted in the negative territory on Monday. Having agreed to sell its Argentinian subsidiary, Deutsche Bank slipped. Because its chairman was no longer at the supervisory board, Stada, a pharmaceutical company, decreased on Monday but gained 2.12% on early Tuesday. A signed contract with Amtrak to build new high-speed trains helped Alstom’s shares go higher. On Tuesday morning, Alstom was 0.10% up. Because its Zika virus test had been authorised by the US Food and Drug Administration, Roche Holdings advanced 0.33%.

Asia-Pacific Market. Thanks to Janet Yellen’s promise to introduce a rate increase this year and the Bank of Japan’s announcement that stimulus would be expanded, if needed, the dollar-yen pair strengthened. The Nikkei grew 2.3% pushed by the good performance of exporters. Canon, Honda Motor, Toyota, and Mazda Motor were among the winners on Monday. The S&P/ASX tumbled 0.8%. The All Ordinaries lost as much. Banks did as poorly in Asia as they did in Europe. Negatively influenced by sinking prices of gold, Newcrest Mining, Norther Star Resources, and Evolution Mining depreciated. Thanks to falling oil prices and the unsolvable problem with the oil supply, energy stocks took a plunge too. Oil Search, Origin Energy, and Woodside Petroleum were in the red. The Shanghai Composite lost minor 0.28 points. The Hang Seng decreased 0.4%. The Kospi shed 0.3% due to the growing dollar. The Sensex climbed 0.4%.
The US is publishing August consumer confidence. The Eurozone is giving final EC business and consumer sentiment. Japan is revealing July household spending, unemployment, and retail sales data.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 31, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_August_31_2016
video.description: Equity markets finished last week down in the US and Europe, and mixed in Asia. The dollar has started to stabilize after heavy losses.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, US dollar, oil, gold

content-body.text: Global stock markets were mixed on Tuesday, 30 August 2016, with European and Asian stocks appreciating and with the US market again characterised by low-volume, unenthusiastic trading. Poorly performing technological companies arrested the US market’s upward movement caused by banks’ gains. Investors around the world continued worrying about interest rates, the timing of which increase is still disturbingly uncertain. Friday’s employment report, bound to influence policymakers’ decision, is another event that weighted on investors’ minds. The indices in the US declined. The Dow Jones was lower 0.3%. The S&P retreated 0.2%. The NASDAQ lost as much. In Europe, apart from the British FTSE that edged 0.3% lower, all other indices advanced. The CAC rose 0.8%. The DAX was 1.1% up. The SMI added 0.6%. On Wednesday morning, however, the DAX and the CAC joined the losers, shedding 0.28% and 0.05% respectively. The US dollar was again strong, while the euro showed signs of weakness. Commodities suffered from the strength of the former. European exporters capitalized on the weakness of the latter.

The US dollar was up against all its major counterparts – the euro, the Swiss franc, the Canadian dollar, the Australian dollar, the pound, and the yen. The yen still suffers the biggest decline. The pound is strengthening a bit. Other currencies, even growing slightly today, are still losing against the US dollar.

Precious metals were doing better on Wednesday morning than they did on Tuesday afternoon. On Tuesday, gold lost US$0.60 to reach US$1,318.15. On Wednesday morning, it rose US$1.85 to US$1,312.96, though it is still significantly down on the month. Silver advanced 0.73% to US$18.81. Platinum added 0.21% to US$1,059.30. WTI Crude oil was down US$0.15 yesterday and US$0.19 today in the morning, trading at US$46.20. Brent Crude lost US$0.29 on Tuesday and US$0.22 to reach US$48.15 on Wednesday morning. Copper sank 0.1% on Tuesday but gained 0.14% on Wednesday morning to US$2.07.

US Market. The deal between Mondelez and Hershey failed to materialize. Mondelez withdrew the offer to buy Hershey that he had made in summer. Mondelez gained 3.95%. Hershey decreased 10.76%. After the European Union had ordered Apple to pay back taxes ($14.5 billion) to Ireland, Apple dropped 0.77%. Having shown poor results in the second quarter and having announced that it would close 60 stores, Abercrombie & Fitch shed 20.31%. Gap was 4.31% lower. Urban Outfitters also dipped, losing 2.53%.

European Market. In contrast to their poor yesterday performance, European banks -- Deutsche Bank, Commerzbank, Société Générale, BNP Paribas, and Crédit Agricole – rose. Automakers again did well. Volkswagen, BMW, Daimler, Peugeot, and Renault stayed in the positive territory. Despite its high half-year profit and revenues, Bunzl, a company that distributes business supplies, edged 0.21% lower. Associated British Foods soared. Because its prognosis for the yearly profits is pessimistic, Braemar Shipping Services tumbled. Thanks to the growing dollar, miners suffered. Antofagasta, Anglo American, Rio Tinto, Glencore, and BHP Billiton ended the trading day in the red. Gold miners -- Randgold Resources and Fresnillo – also slipped, losing 2.17% and 1.95% respectively.

Asia-Pacific Market. As was the case in Europe, banks in Asia, including Mitsubishi UFJ Financial, Mizuho Financial and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial, had a good day and boosted the Shanghai Composite 0.2% up. They also brought Hang Seng 0.9% higher. Because July household spending and retail sales were depressingly low and because the unemployment rate was as low as it had not been in two decades, The Nikkei inched 0.1% down. East Japan Railway, Asahi Group, NTT DoCoMo, and Softbank slipped. Hitachi advanced. In Australia, the S&P/ASX added 0.2%. The All Ordinaries gained as much. Banks were mixed. ANZ, Commonwealth, and NAB appreciated. Westpac experienced a decline. Santos and Woodside Petroleum were slightly up thanks to better oil prices on Tuesday. Ramsay Health Care ended the trading day in the green. The Kospi surged 0.4%. The Sensex soared 1.6%.

The US is issuing August ADP private employment and Chicago PMI. It is also giving July pending home sales index and weekly EIA petroleum status report. Canada is posting June monthly and second quarter GDP. The Eurozone is reporting on August flash harmonized index of consumer prices and July unemployment. Germany is announcing August unemployment. Japan is issuing July industrial production.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: September 01, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_September_01_2016
video.description: Equity markets finished last week down in the US and Europe, and mixed in Asia. The dollar has started to stabilize after heavy losses.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, US dollar, oil, gold

content-body.text: On Wednesday, the 31st of August 2016, global markets repeated the pattern observable on the previous day, Tuesday. The US market dropped again. Both European and Asian markets were again mixed. As it has been the case almost for the whole month of August, trading was lacklustre. Suffering from falling oil prices, energy companies were again in decline. Chemical companies dropped equally low. Disheartened by lack of clarity surrounding a promised rates hike, investors lowered their activities at markets, refusing to make moves before the publication of the employment report on Friday. The persistent problem with oil oversupply continued driving everyone out of humour. In the Asia-Pacific region, Japanese stocks performed well lifted by the weakening yen and unexpectedly optimistic US consumer confidence data. Australian stocks, undermined by the rapid selling of resource shares, limited the upside, however, and pushed the whole market lower. The Dow Jones industrials shed 0.3% on Wednesday afternoon and remained equally low on Thursday morning. The S&P dropped 0.2% on both days. The NASDAQ sank 0.2% on Wednesday but inched a bit higher on Thursday morning. In August overall, the Dow Jones lost 0.2%. The S&P was 0.1% lower. The NASDAQ was the only index that finished the month in the green, adding 1.0%. On Wednesday, the FTSE declined 0.6% but rallied on Thursday morning, adding 0.31%. The DAX slipped 0.6% on Wednesday but was 0.74% up in the morning on Thursday. The CAC first retreated 0.4% but rose 1.16% on Thursday. The SMI, likewise, had a 0.4% slide on Wednesday. For the whole month of August, the CAC remained virtually unchanged. The FTSE added 0.8%. The DAX jumped 2.5%. The SMI edged 0.9% higher in the last month of summer.

On Wednesday, the US dollar lost its leadership among other currencies maintained by it almost through the whole week and retreated against the euro, pound, and the Australian dollar. The US dollar remained unchanged against the Australian dollar and advanced against the week yen and the falling Canadian dollar.

The strong dollar continued pressurising precious metals that did poorly on Wednesday but managed to inch slightly higher on Thursday morning. On Wednesday afternoon, gold dropped US$8.90 to US$1,309.25. Copper was unchanged trading at US$2.08. WTI spot crude lost US$1.54 to US$44.81. Dated Brent spot crude shed US$1.33 to US$47.04. On Thursday morning, commodities charts looked more upbeat: apart from gold, all major commodities were in the positive territory. Silver was 0.02% up to reach US$18.73. Platinum advanced US$0.39 to US$1,502.50. WTI spot crude was 0.08% higher to US$46.91. Copper added 1.00% to US$2.08.

US Market. Because it had sold its bank business and reported losses in the first-quarter, H&R Block sank 10.50%. Having demonstrated low sales, Brown-Forman Corporation, an American company that produces spirits and wine, shed 3.54%. Thanks to the accumulation of crude oil stockpiles that already reached 2.3 million barrels this week, energy stocks tumbled. Chevron kept on dipping losing 1.10% on Wednesday. Exxon Mobil declined 0.43%. Schlumberger followed suit and finished the day 2.03% lower.

European Market. Due to falling prices of gold, mining stocks continue sinking, as did gold-mining companies. Anglo American, BHP Billiton, Fresnillo, Antofagasta, Glencore, Rio Tinto, and Randgold Resources slipped. Banks were again in the green. Commerzbank and Deutsche Bank did particularly well on Wednesday on rumours that they might merge. Société Générale, Crédit Agricole, and BNP Paribas also advanced. Barclays, HSBC Holdings, and Lloyds Banking Group soared bolstered by good reports on the healing British economy.

Asia-Pacific Market. Property stocks jumped and brought the Shanghai Composite up 0.4%. Hang Seng, by contrast, shed 0.2%. In August, the former index was 3.6% higher. The latter advanced 5.0%. Helped by the weakened yen, the Nikkei rose 1.0% on Wednesday but was slightly lower on Thursday morning (up 0.23%). Exporters gained as they usually do, when the yen falls. Canon, Panasonic, Toshiba, and Mazda Motor finished the trading session in the positive territory. After the Nikkei had said that Google was going to make a deal with Japan’s largest bank to launch its digital wallet platform, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial soared. Australian indices were in trouble hit by the stronger dollar. Both the S&P/ASX and the All Ordinaries had a 0.8% slide. On Wednesday morning, the S&P/ASX gained a bit but not enough to move out of the negative sphere, being 0.32% lower. For the month of August, both S&P/ASX and the All Ordinaries decreased 2.0%. Even though iron prices started to recover from losses, mining companies retreated. BHP Billiton, Fortescue Metals, and Rio Tinto tumbled. Gold-mining companies did too, negatively affected by low prices of gold. Newcrest Mining, Evolution Mining, Northern Star Resources, and Regis Resources slumbered. The Kospi ended the day 0.2% lower but appreciated 0.9% in August as a whole. The Sensex reached its highest level in more than a year, going 0.4% up on Wednesday. The Indian index advanced 1.4% in August.

The US is publishing second quarter productivity & costs, August manufacturing PMI, the ISM manufacturing index, and July construction spending. It is also giving weekly jobless claims, money supply, and Fed balance sheet. In Asia, China is publishing August CFLP and Market manufacturing PMIs. Japan and India are reporting on final August manufacturing PMI. Australia is giving July retail sales and quarterly new capital expenditures data. Eurozone, Germany, France, Italy, and the UK are posting final manufacturing PMIs.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: September 04, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_September_04_2016
video.description: Equity markets finished last week down in the US and Europe, and mixed in Asia. The dollar has started to stabilize after heavy losses.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, US dollar, oil, gold

content-body.text: Thursday, 1 September 2016, was again a slow day charged with anxiety over the forthcoming Friday US August job reports liable to make an impact on Federal Reserve’s decision whether to increase rates this year. Trajectories of global markets were different on Thursday. Starting lower, the US stocks managed to gather strength during the day and entered the positive territory by its closure. European stocks moved in a polar opposite direction, starting the day optimistically but declining as trading progressed, negatively influenced by a bad beginning of the trading day in the US. Like European market, the Asian stocks also finished mostly in the red, even though oil prices jumped in the region and China published the best CFLP manufacturing PMI in almost two years -- it jumped to 50.4. In the US, by contrast, manufacturing data was surprisingly poor. Manufacturing activities fell from 52.6 in July to 49.4 in August. Vehicle sales were also disappointing, having dropped from 17.9 million in July to 17.0 million in the last day of summer. Indices in the US inched slightly higher, with the Dow Jones industrial adding 0.1% and with the NASDAQ jumping 0.3%. The S&P did not change. Indices in Europe slid. The FTSE shed 0.5%. The DAX dropped 0.6%. The SMI dipped 0.7%. The CAC remained the same from the day before. IBEX in Spain climbed 0.5%, even though, in all likelihood, Spanish Prime Minister will not be elected for a second term.
Thursday was a bad day for the US dollar. It slipped against all its major counterparts – the yen, the British pound, the Swiss franc, the Australian dollar, the Canadian dollar, and the euro.

On Thursday afternoon, major commodities were mixed. Gold appreciated US$0.25 to reach US$1,309.50. Copper futures remained at US$2.08. WTI spot crude declined US$1.19 to US$43.51. Dated Brent spot crude lost US$1.15 to US$45.74.

US Market. Retailers did poorly on Thursday, weakened by bad reports from Costco Wholesale and Campbell Soup. Although these two companies managed to rally on Friday, on Thursday, their shares significantly fell. Both of the companies reported weak sales in August. Salesforce.com boasted good profits but also slipped undermined by its third-quarter guidance. Energy stocks continued slipping, brought lower by falling oil prices. Only material companies were in the green, thereby reining in the market’s downward drifting. Because the Brazilian Oil company Petrobras had announced the premature termination of its contract with Diamond Offshore Drilling, the stocks of the latter sank. Thanks to its good second-quarter reports, Ollie’s Bargain Outlet Holdings appreciated. Charter Communications that had recently bought Time Warner Cable and Bright House Networks also climbed.

European Market. After solid gains during the week, banks were mixed. Commerzbank continued appreciating. Deutsche Bank, by contrast, ended the day lower. Thanks to new complaints about its emission testing filed in Australia, Volkswagen lost on Thursday. E.ON dipped, and so did RWE. After it reported a 2.0% rise in full-year profit, Pernod Ricard added 1.57%. Technicolor also advanced. Having placed $650 million convertible bonds due 2023, Inmarsat climbed. Stocks of Hays retreated, after the company warned about the unstable condition of its UK and Irish markets. Low oil prices pulled Royal Dutch Shell and BP down.

Asia-Pacific Market. The Shanghai Composite shed 0.7% mainly due to the falling stocks of financial and property developers. The Hang Seng, by contrast, did well on Thursday, adding 0.8%. Thanks to the weak yen, the Nikkei rose, as always helped by exporters. Takeda Pharma, Kawasaki Heavy Industries, and Alps Electric soared. Just as they did in Europe, energy shares dipped also in the Asia-Pacific region. Inpex had a slide along with Japan Petroleum. Santos and Origin Energy finished in the negative territory as well. Australian indices tumbled. The S&P/ASX dropped 0.3%. The All Ordinaries lost as much. Mining companies retreated, just as energy shares did. Hit by iron ore prices that had sank to their four-week low, Rio Tinto slumped. Banks -- Westpac, NAB, and ANZ -- managed to reap gains. Woolworths also advanced. The Kospi edged 0.1% down. The Sensex was equally low.

The Eurozone is publishing July producer price indices. The US is giving July international trade data, and so is Canada. The US is also reporting on August employment situation and on July factory orders.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: September 05, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_September_05_2016
video.description: Equity markets finished last week down in the US and Europe, and mixed in Asia. The dollar has started to stabilize after heavy losses.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, US dollar, oil, gold

content-body.text: On Friday, 02 September 2016, the long-awaited US report came and pushed the stocks higher but not because it brought good news. Quite the contrary, the report showed that far less than expected jobs had been created at the job market in August. There was an addition of only 151,000 jobs, which is lesser than 275,000 jobs added in July. The unemployment rate remained unchanged at 4.9%. Investors, however, shrugged the upsetting news off, explaining the insufficient growth of jobs as seasonally inevitable. August reports traditionally come out weaker than in other months. Poor employment reports failed to drive investors out of humour also because they are expected to prevent Federal Reserve policymakers from pushing rates higher in September. Investors’ nonchalant attitude to the bad job reports became more soar, however, at the beginning of the week, causing the dollar to plummet on Monday. All indices advanced on Friday. American indices appreciated 0.4% on Friday. Since the last week, the Dow Jones industrials soared 0.5%. The S&P also rose 0.5%. The NASDAQ was 0.6% higher for the week. In Europe, all indices also jumped on the last trading day of the week and remained equally high on Monday morning as well. The FTSE soared 2.2%. The CAC appreciated 2.3%. The DAX was 1.4% higher. The SMI climbed 1.9%. Since the previous week, the FTSE rose 0.8%; the CAC added 2.3%. The DAX edged 0.9% higher. The SMI was 1.5% up.
The US dollar declined against all its major counterparts on Monday morning – the euro, the yen, the Swiss franc, the Australian dollar, the Canadian dollar, and the British pound.

On Monday morning, all major commodities were in the green. Gold added US1.59 to US$1,326.80. Silver advanced 0.54% to US$19.47. Platinum appreciated 0.41% to US$1,068.25. WTI Crude Oil advanced 0.87% to US$45.31. Brent Crude rose 0.11% to reach US$46.88. Copper soared US$0.70 to US$2.08.

US Market. Oil prices rose slightly and immediately brought shares of energy companies higher. Stocks of tobacco, steel, and telecom companies were also in the green on Friday. Utilities companies also did well. Biotechnical and pharmaceutical companies tumbled, knocked down by Hillary Clinton’s new pricing plan. Mylan lost 4.65%. Companies that make household goods jumped. Colgate-Palmolive added 0.83%. Tyson Foods rose 1.27%. Reynolds American gained 1.93%. Altria Group was 0.85% higher. Having shown poor revenue, VeriFone Systems dipped, complaining about a slow adoption of chip cards payments.

European Market. Banks were strong again. Having promised to acquire 85% equity stake in the Indian dialysis group, Fresenius Medical Care advanced, though it shed 0.05% on Monday morning. BMW, Daimler, and Volkswagen finished the day higher. Because its half-year profit was much less than expected, Rocket Internet retreated 1.29%. Accor jumped 1.25%, and so did Go-Ahead Group. Miners and gold miners -- Fresnillo, Anglo American, Randgold, and Glencore – climbed. Royal Dutch Shell and BP were in the green, too.

Asia-Pacific Market. The Shanghai composite rose 0.1% on Friday and slipped 0.1% since the last week. The Hang Seng soared 0.5% on the day and 1.6% for the week. Although it did not change on Friday, shedding minor 1.16 points, the Nikkei was 3.5% higher on the week. Kansai Electric Power, Dai-ichi Life Insurance, Chugai Pharmaceutical, and J Front Retailing surged. Toshiba and Sony picked. Because their August sales fell below expectations, Toyota Motor and Honda Motor slipped. Tokyo Dome rose. Australian shares continued dipping. The S&P/ASX shed 0.8%. The All Ordinaries decreased 0.7%. From the last Friday, the S&P/ASX lost 2.6%. The All Ordinaries declined 2.4% for the week. The banks were lower, and so were Beach Energy and Woodside Petroleum. BHP Billiton moved into the positive territory, and so did Rio Tinto. Because gold climbed, gold mining companies -- Northern Star Resources, Newcrest, Regis Resources, and Evolution Mining -- surged. The Kospi edged 0.3% higher. The Sensex appreciated 0.4% on Friday.

On the 5th of September, Japan and Eurozone are publishing August Composite PMI. On the 6th of September, the Reserve Bank of Australia is making monetary policy announcement. The Eurozone is reporting on Eurozone Gross Domestic Product in the second quarter. The US is giving August Services PMI.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: September 07, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_September_07_2016
video.description: Equity markets finished last week down in the US and Europe, and mixed in Asia. The dollar has started to stabilize after heavy losses.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, US dollar, oil, gold

content-body.text: Markets were mixed on Tuesday, 06 September 2016. The US and Asian markets finished the trading session planted in the positive territory, even though the US market vacillated between losses and gains throughout the day. European market was unfavourably influenced by early losses in America. ISM nonmanufacturing report that proved to be disappointing also put investors out of humour and tempered their trading enthusiasm. Investors’ initial optimism about the conversation between Russia and Saudi Arabia gave way to gloominess, once they realized that the two countries would not agree to curb oil production. During their meeting, Saudi Arabia said it sees no need to limit oil output; Russia agreed that a cap is not required. All talks about oil freeze seems to be pure eyewash: oil producing countries continue pumping with undiminished zeal. Iran is already moving closer to achieving the goal of pre-sanctions level production. Russia is producing more than 11 million barrels a day; OPEC countries together are giving 33.69 million barrels a day at present. Affected by the combination of these discouraging data, European stocks declined. The FTSE shed 0.8% on Tuesday afternoon and was 0.03% down in the morning on Wednesday. The CAC slipped 0.2% in the evening and 0.05% on Wednesday early morning. The SMI was down 0.1%. The DAX managed to finish 0.1% higher on Tuesday but decreased 0.02% in the morning on Wednesday. The US indices appreciated. The Dow Jones rose 0.2% on both days; the S&P edged 0.3% higher; the NASDAQ appreciated 0.5%.

Because Federal Reserve Labour Market conditions index was negative, falling to its lowest level since February 2010, the US dollar dropped 0.5% on Wednesday, losing against all its major counterparts – the euro, the British pound, the Australian dollar, the Swiss franc, the yen, and the Canadian dollar.

On Wednesday morning, all commodities advanced apart from silver that slightly slipped. WTI Crude Oil was 0.45% to reach US$45.03. Brent Crude advanced 0.44% to US$47.47. Gold rose 0.09% to US$ 1,351.17. Silver dipped 0.34% to US$20.07. Platinum climbed 0.35% to US$1,102.59. Copper added 0.81% to US$2.10.

US Market. Helped by growing oil prices, energy stocks did well on Tuesday. NextEra energy rose 1.75%. AES Corporation was 4.99% higher. Having promised to buy the oil and natural gas company Yates Petroleum for $2.3 billion, EOG Resources gained 6.66%. After it agreed to purchase the molecular diagnostics company Cepheid for $4 billion, Danaher, an industrial and medical device company, soared, though it declined slightly on Wednesday. Banks were the biggest losers on Tuesday. Lincoln National dropped 2.21%; Citigroup retreated 0.46%. Navistar jumped. Cummins, a corporation that designs, manufactures, and distributes engines, filtration, and power generation products, lost 7.31%.

European Market. After it had agreed to purchase IDC Salud Holding S.L.U. for €5.76 billion, shares of Fresenius climbed. General Electric talked about buying Sweden's Arcam AB and Germany's SLM Solutions Group for $1.4 billion and immediately shed 0.77%. In the wake of the negotiations with General Electric, SLM was 1.49% lower on Wednesday. Arcam, by contrast, gained 2.11%. French airbus Group finished the day in the green, while Ingenico Group lost on Tuesday. The latter managed to rebound on Wednesday early morning, adding 0.31%. Aircraft companies did well in the UK. International Consolidated Airlines Group was higher, and so was EayJet. Redrow proposed a 67% growth in its full year dividend and advanced, dropping, however, 1.61% in the morning on Wednesday. Berkley Group counted gains. Standard Chartered along with Provident Financial finished the trading session in the negative territory.

Asia-Pacific Market. Thanks to the good performance of consumer and industrial companies, the Shanghai Composite rose 0.6%. The Hang Seng was equally higher. Because the yen fell on Tuesday, the Nikkei edged 0.3% up. On Wednesday morning, however, when the yen rose to 114.16, the Japanese index slipped 0.41%. Sumitomo Chemical, Dai-ichi Life Insurance, Nippon Suisan Kaisha, and Shiseido advanced on Tuesday, as did also Kyowa Hakko Kirin. Because the Reserve Bank of Australia had decided to keep its policy interest rate at 1.5%, the Australian indices tumbled. The S&P/ASX decreased 03%. The All Ordinaries lost as much. On Wednesday morning, however, the S&P/ASX inched 0.20% higher. Unlike European banks that sank, Australian banks were mixed. ANZ did not change much. Commonwealth rose 1.11%. Westpac was 1.62% higher. NAB edged 0.36% up on Wednesday morning. Mining companies – BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metal Group surged. The Kospi gained 0.3%. The Sensex appreciated 1.6% helped by investors from other countries.

The Federal Reserve is publishing its Beige Book. The Bank of Canada is announcing its monetary policy decision. The US is giving JOLTS for July. Australia is reporting on second quarter gross domestic product. Germany is issuing July industrial production. The UK is doing the same.

video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: September 08, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_September_08_2016
video.description: Equity markets finished last week down in the US and Europe, and mixed in Asia. The dollar has started to stabilize after heavy losses.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, US dollar, oil, gold

content-body.text:
Trading was uneventful on Wednesday, 07 September 2016. Not expecting rates hike by Federal Reserve in September, investors worried about the economy and the earning power of companies. The Federal Reserve published its Beige Book ahead of its FOMC meeting on the 21st and the 22nd of September. The US economy’s growth was described in it as modest. Wage pressures for highly skilled workers were described as increased; the Beige Book also talked about the difficulty of filling job vacancies for technology specialists, engineers, and construction workers. Consumer spending remained unchanged.

The US market was brought low by weak data from supermarkets, consumer focused companies, and material companies. The only stocks that closed higher on Wednesday were energy ones, lifted by growing oil crude prices. The Dow Jones industrials dropped 0.1% on Wednesday and was 0.06% lower on Thursday morning. The S&P remained the same, losing 0.33 points on Wednesday and 0.01% early in the morning on Thursday. The NASDAQ was the only index that appreciated both on Wednesday and Thursday, adding 0.2% and 0.15% respectively. European markets were pressurised by disappointing information about German industrial production. Yet having struggled in the morning, European markets managed to end the trading session in the green. The FTSE added 0.3% on Wednesday and 0.51% on Thursday morning. The DAX and CAC rose 0.6% on Wednesday. The former gained 0.22% and the latter rose 0.24% on Thursday in the morning. The SMI was 0.3% higher. Asian market was mixed, weakened by volatile oil prices and the firmer yen.
On Thursday morning, the dollar continued slipping retreating against almost all other currencies apart from the Swiss franc.

On Thursday morning, the majority of commodities advanced. Only Copper slightly retreated. WTI Crude Oil added 1.78% to reach US$46.31. Brent Crude gained 1.52% to US$48.71. Gold spot was 0.17% higher to US$1,347.48. Silver rose 0.67% to US$19.99. Copper slid 0.07% to US$2.09. Platinum appreciated 0.24% to US$1,092.50.

US Market. Supermarkets and consumer oriented companies did particularly badly on Wednesday. Material companies also drifted lower. What helped the US market keep a balance without sliding totally down were energy stocks that rose thanks to growing crude oil prices. After it said that it would drill crude oil in the field in Texas that had been recently discovered, Apache gained. Kroger declined 4.13%. Whole Food Markets slipped 5.28%. Sprouts Farmers Market lost whooping 13.72%. Having showed disappointing sales, Dave & Buster’s Entertainment dipped 2.9%. After Pershing Square had bought 9.9% stake in Chipotle Mexican Grill, the restaurant jumped. Seagate Technology and Western Digital finished the day in the positive territory. American airlines added along with Delta Airlines, United Continental Holdings, and Southwest Airlines. Apple had presented a new iPhone and soared.

European Market. Due to its negotiations with Anhui Jianghuai Automobile concerning the production of electric vehicles, Volkswagen rose. Other automakers – BMW and Daimler – followed suit and also appreciated. Having said that it had an increase in first-quarter pretax profit, Ashtead Group jumped. Foreseeing low profits this year, Sports Direct International declined. Barratt Developments did as well. Just Eat lost 0.65%. Thanks to growing oil prices, BP and Royal Dutch Shell closed higher. Influenced by investors’ worries about Brexit’s effects on the European economy, Berkley Group retreated.

Asian Market. The Shanghai Composite stayed the same, adding minor 1.22 points. The Hang Seng shed 0.2%, negatively affected by the report showing that China’s foreign exchange reserves fell to $3.19 trillion in August. Because the yen went up, the Nikkei slid 0.45%. For the same reason, exporters dropped. Sharp, Panasonic, and Mazda Motor drifted lower on Wednesday. Inpex, Fast Retailing, and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial dipped. Rakuten, excited to join the Nikkei, soared. In Australia, things looked up for indices. The S&P/ASX added 0.2%. The All Ordinaries advanced as much. The big four banks jumped. Wesfarmers gained, and so did Myer Holdings. Thanks to rising gold, goldminers -- Newcrest, Regis Resources, Evolution Mining, and Northern Star Resources – surged. Santos slipped, and so did Fortescue Metals Group. The Kospi shed 0.2%. The Sensex lost as much, prevented from bigger losses by the growing rupee.

The US is publishing weekly jobless claims, EIA petroleum status report, money supply, and Fed balance sheet. The European Central Bank is announcing its monetary policy decision. Australia is giving July merchandise trade data. Japan is posting revised second quarter gross domestic product.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: September 12, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_September_12_2016
video.description: Equity markets finished last week down in the US and Europe, and mixed in Asia. The dollar has started to stabilize after heavy losses.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, US dollar, oil, gold

content-body.text: Stock markets plummeted drastically on Friday and were still down on Monday morning. Investors were greatly troubled by the announcements of the probable increase of rates in September made by the Boston Federal Reserve Bank President Eric Rosengren and echoed by Dallas Federal President Robert Kaplan. In Europe and Asia, investors’ mood was further worsened by the decision of the European Central Bank to maintain its monetary policy unchanged. Poor economic data from Germany, France, and China also weakened everyone’s optimism about the economic future of the world. North Korea’s statement that it had successfully tested nuclear warhead weighted heavily on investors’ minds, too, triggering geopolitical worries. The decline of oil prices was also upsetting, as were Australian home loan data. The majority of indices tumbled on Friday; all of them were in the red on Monday morning. The Down Jones shed 2.1% on Friday and was 2.2% lower for the week. The S&P slid 2.5% for the day and 2.4% since the last Friday. The NASDAQ retreated 2.5% on Friday and 2.4% for the week. European indices sank equally low. The FTSE slipped 1.2% on Friday and 1.7% on the week. On Monday morning the index dropped 1.3%. The CAC lost 1.1% on Friday and as much from the last week. On Monday morning, it was 1.8% down. The DAX plummeted 1.0% both on Friday and for the week. On Monday, it dipped 1.8%. The SMI sank 0.9% on Friday and 0.4% since the last week.

Low commodities prices hurt the Australian and Canadian dollars, which retreated against the US dollar. The yen gained slightly on the US dollar. The euro and the British pound rose a bit, advancing against the US dollar. Mr Rosengren’s intimations that rates would go up in September are generally looked at as a tactic to talk up the dollar.

Save gold, all commodities lost on Friday and continued to be in the negative sphere on Monday morning. WTI Crude Oil lost 1.85% to US$45.03. Brent Crude was 1.71% down to reach US$47.19. Gold advanced 0.41% trading at US$1,329.72. Silver shed 1.82% to US$19.02. Copper retreated 1.12% to US$2.06. Platinum dipped 0.56% to US$1,056.45.

US Markets. Utilities, phone companies, and real estate corporations were at the forefront of losing companies, pulled down by the announcements of probable rates hike in September. Negatively influenced by falling oil prices, oil and gas production companies slipped as well. Drilling companies retreated for the same reason. Diamond Offshore Drilling lost whooping 10.34%. The energy corporation, Williams Companies, shed 3.56%. Transocean, an offshore drilling constructor, sank 6.11%. Shares of SL Green Realty Corporation, a real estate investment trust, dropped 4.79%. A&AT finished the trading day also lower, shedding 3.57%. Ventas followed suit and closed lower as well. Among these losers, only Restoration Hardware and Finisar advanced. The former soared 3.09%. Finisar, a manufacturer of optical communication components and subsystems, surged 12.79%.

European Markets. Due to rumours that it is about to close an agreement with the US Department of Justice to start an investigation of the sale of mortgage-backed securities, Deutsche Bank appreciated. Aiming to buy Monsanto, for which it would need to sell its dermatology business, Bayer, a German multinational chemical and pharmaceutical company, had a 2.46% slide. Because it said it would want to buy 75% of Chesapeake’s shares in their shared Barnet Shale Company, Total lost 2.03%. British Burberry finished the trading session in the negative territory. Greene King was also in the red by the day’s closure. Having said that its fiscal pre-tax profit rose, pub chain JD Wetherspoon added on Friday but slid 4.12% on Monday morning. Banks had a good day on Friday: Royal Bank of Scotland, Barclays, Lloyds Banking Group, and HSBC ended up in the green.

Asia-Pacific Region. China’s August consumer prices advanced 1.3% for the whole year but were lower than in July, when they advanced 1.7%. The Shanghai Composite lost 0.6 on Friday. Yet it was 0.4% higher since the last week. The Hang Seng advanced 0.8% on Friday and 3.6% on the week. The index, however, declined 2.93% on Monday morning. The Nikkei added insignificant 6.99 points on the day and advanced 0.2% since the last Friday. But it lost 1.73% on Monday in the morning. As was the case in Europe, telephone companies fared badly on Friday. NTT DoCoMo, Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, and Kirin dipped. Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha, Sumitomo Heavy Industries, Kobe Steel, Nippon Yusen KK, and J Front Retailing, by contrast, soared. In Australia, indices continued losing. The S&P/ASX shed 0.8% on Friday and 0.6% on the week. The All Ordinaries retreated as much on both occasions. Big banks sank. Even though oil prices went down, miners managed to keep in the positive territory on Friday, dropping low, however, in the morning on Monday. BHP Billiton slipped 4.04%. Rio Tinto edged 2.45% lower. Fortescue Metal Group plummeted 5.05%. The Bank of Korea continued having their interest at the lowest possible level of 1.25%, thereby negatively influencing the Kospi index. The announcement of North Korea about the successful trial of a miniaturised nuclear warhead also had a role in pushing the Kospi down. On Friday, the index sank 1.3%, remaining unchanged from the previous week. The Sensex dipped 0.9% on the day and was equally low since the last Friday.

On the 12th of September, Japan is presenting Producer Price Index for August and July Machine orders. India is giving August Consumer Price Index and Industrial Production for July. On the 13th of September, Germany is publishing ZEW Survey for September. Italy is reporting on July Industrial Production. The UK is issuing August Consumer Price Index and Producer Price Index also for August. China is presenting a report on August Industrial Production together with August Retail Sales.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: September 14, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_September_14_2016
video.description: Equity markets finished last week down in the US and Europe, and mixed in Asia. The dollar has started to stabilize after heavy losses.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, US dollar, oil, gold

content-body.text: On Tuesday, 13 September 2016, stocks retreated worldwide, though some Asian indices managed to pull it off and partially ended the trading day in the positive territory. The S&P 500 dropped to its lowest level since the 7th of July 2016, losing 1.48%. Treasuries also slid. Crude oil sank 3%, trading below US$45 a barrel, after the International Energy Agency had expressed an opinion that world stockpiles of oil will continue growing in 2017, for the fourth consecutive year. The International Energy Agency foresees that global demand for oil will be only 1.3 barrels a day, which is insufficient to solve the problem with oil glut. The gloomy outlook on oil oversupply immediately brought energy companies down. Banks and phone companies also sank, undermined by investors’ anxiety over rates increase. The Dow Jones industrials shed 1.4%; the NASDAQ was 1.09% lower. The European indices shuttled between gains and losses during the day but were eventually weakened by the poor performance of the US stocks. Falling oil prices also precipitated European markets’ retreat. The FTSE lost 0.53%. The DAX slipped 0.43%. The CAC ended 1.19% lower. The SMI dipped 0.4%. The Sensex in India was closed for the holiday.

The yen tumbled 0.7% against the US dollar. Everyone expects now that Bank of Japan will push its negative interest rates further. The pound hit its weakest level in five weeks and again stirred up anxiety over the UK’s unstable economy after Brexit vote. The dollar also lost versus the euro, the Swiss franc, and the Canadian and Australian dollars. Mexican peso retreated the most among emerging-market currencies.

Crude lost 3% and traded at US$44.90, though it rose slightly on Wednesday morning, trading now at US$45.18. Gold sank, marking an 11/2 week low. It has been declining for five consecutive sessions already, which is its longest run of losses in a month. It traded at US$1,319.05 on Tuesday and US$1,321.60 on Wednesday morning. Silver appreciated 0.16% to reach US$19.03. Brent Crude added 0.68% to US$47.28. Copper rose 2.15% to US$2.12. Platinum advanced 0.82% to US$1,040.83.

US Markets. Energy stocks tumbled along with bank and phone companies. The latter were brought lower by higher bonds yields. Transocean, Baker Hughes, Exxon Mobil, Chevron, and Murphy Oil led losses on Tuesday. After Anadarko Petroleum made a deal with Freeport-MCMoRan’s deepwater assets in the Gulf of Mexico, shares of both companies dipped. Renesas of Japan offered to purchase Intersil for $3.05 billion, after which the latter advanced. Wells Fargo shed 3.26%. Goldman Sachs was 2.41% lower. Verizon slipped 2.13%. AT&T had a 1.82% slide. After T-Mobile had announced that Apple’s new iPhone was selling well, Apple soared, adding 2.55%. Because it had said that its chief executive is about to retire, Weight Watchers plummeted 6.56%.

European Markets. E.ON continued falling together with RWE. Air Liquide in France added after it had introduced a share capital increase. Technip ended the trading session in the red, and so did Total. On Wednesday morning, however, the former soared 1.23%. Total remained 0.01% lower. Having given record half-year profits, JD Spots gained in London on Tuesday, though it shed 0.90% on Wednesday morning. After it had said that the growth of its volume and profit was good, Hilton Food Group advanced 4.58%. Associated British Food slipped on Tuesday but managed to edge 0.73% higher on Wednesday morning. Tullow Oil slid on Tuesday but inched 0.04% higher the next day. Royal Dutch Shell also rose 0.46% after dropping on Tuesday.

Asia-Pacific Market. China’s August industrial output was 6.3%, which is higher than in July (6.0%) but significantly lower than in March, when it was as high as 6.8%. Retail sales were also better than in July, growing to 10.6%. These good data boosted the Shanghai Composite 0.1% up. Hang Seng, by contrast, lost 0.3%. On Tuesday, the Nikkei edged 0.3% up thanks to the stable yen. On Wednesday morning, however, when the yen tumbled 0.7%, the Nikkei had a 0.69% slide. As was the case in the US, banks were at the forefront of losing companies. Mitsubishi UFJ Financial slumped 3.17%. Mizuho Financial Group were 1.03% down. Sumitomo Financial dipped 0.99%. In Australia, stocks dipped after having made profits. The S&P/ASX retreated 0.2%. The All Ordinaries lost as much. Because oil prices started sinking again, energy stocks tumbled. Origin Energy plummeted 2.17%. Oil Search slid 0.93%. Santos closed 5.65% lower. Having promised to pay off US$700 million of its debt, Fortescue Metal Group gained. BHP Billiton soared along with Rio Tinto. The Kospi edged 0.4% higher

On the 15th of September, the Bank of England is announcing its monetary policy. The UK is also showing its August Retail Sales. The Swiss National Bank is assessing its monetary policy. Eurozone is giving a report on July Merchandise Trade and Harmonized Index of Consumer Prices for August. The US is announcing Initial Unemployment Claims. It is also reporting on August Retail Sales, August Producer Price Index, September Empire State Survey, September Philadelphia Fed Survey, and August Industrial Production.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: September 15, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_September_15_2016
video.description: Prices of oil continue dropping along with precious metals. The USD advanced against some currencies. Indices are mixed.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market analysis, Forex, Forex trading, gold, silver, US dollar, indices, crude oil.

content-body.text: On Wednesday, the 14th of September 2016, trading was less volatile than at the beginning of the week. Investors curbed their activities in expectations of policy decisions from several banks forthcoming shortly. Today, the Bank of England is holding a meeting, during which it is expected to make no major changes to its current monetary policy. Investors believe that the Bank of England will continue pursuing monetary easing by maintaining its large asset purchase program and its low interest rates. Investors’ other concern is the monetary policy of the Bank of Japan, which will be announced next week. Everyone predicts that the Bank of Japan will increase negative interest rather than expand asset purchases. What, however, arouses investors’ keenest interest is the meeting of the Federal Reserve held next week. The question that has been bothering everyone since the last December is whether the Federal Reserve is going to push interest rates higher. Anxious about the Federal Reserve’s decision, investors refrained from making significant moves on Wednesday. Sliding oil prices also weighed on their sentiments as they watched shares of energy companies going lower. Investors’ worries were, however, tempered by good performance of technology stocks led by Apple that counterbalanced the US markets’ losses. The markets ended the trading session mixed, therefore: the Dow Jones industrials and the S&P slipped 1.18% and 0.06% respectively and the NASDAQ surged 0.36%. In Europe, only the FTSE rose 0.12%; other indices dropped. The DAX lost 0.08%; the CAC retreated 0.39%; the SMI declined 0.1%. In Asia, most of the indices sank on Wednesday. On Thursday morning, however, the Hang Seng managed to add 0.86% and the S&P/ASX jumped 0.23% higher.

The US dollar advanced versus the Euro and the Swiss franc, though it decreased against the yen and the British pound. The disappointing Australian unemployment data brought the Australian dollar to its lowest level since July 25. The AUD/USD pair fell to 0.7450. Sinking oil prices negatively influenced the Canadian dollar that on Thursday morning was trading only at 1.3232.

Oil continues dipping. WTI Crude Oil is trading on Thursday morning at US$43.65. Brent Crude is inexorably approaching equally low prices. On Wednesday in the morning, it traded at US$46.06. Because, apprehensive of the forthcoming rate increase, traders invest more willingly now in the US dollar than in the safe haven, precious metals, gold, silver, and platinum depreciated. Gold spot lost 0.17% to reach US$1,320.74. Silver declined 0.42% and is trading now at US$18.99. Platinum was 0.20% lower to reach US$1,034.94. Copper was up 0.23% to US$2.16.

US Market. Low oil prices pushed energy companies down. Chevron lost 1.02%. Marathon Oil declined 2.30%. Apple continued growing boosted by good preorders of its new iPhone. Anticipating a fall of its pretax profit and poor results throughout 2017, Ford Motor retreated. After Allergan had signed a takeover of Vitae Pharmaceuticals, the latter advanced whooping 157.41%. Having said that its third quarter profit would be smaller than expected, Nucor, an American producer of steel, dropped 1.46%. Cracker Barrel Old Country Store followed suit and also declined. Monsanto and Bayer had finally signed a deal, according to which Bayer, the German drug and farm chemical company, buys Monsanto for $57 billion in cash. After this deal, Monsanto added 0.62%. Bayer had a 0.59% slide.

European Market. After it had said that it anticipated poor earnings in the second half of the year, Hermes International sank on Wednesday but succeeded in climbing 0.10% on Thursday morning. Other luxury goods companies also suffered a decline. LVMH, Kering, and Burberry were down, though LVMH and Kering rose slightly on Thursday morning. British Galliford Try reported high annual profit and advanced on Wednesday, falling, however, 0.11% on Thursday morning. Compass Group ended higher. Mining companies appreciated: Glencore, Anglo American, Antofagasta, BHP Billiton, and Randgold Resources ended the day in the positive territory.

Asia-Pacific Market. Because everyone expects that the Bank of Japan is about to increase its negative rate policy, the Nikkei dropped 0.7% on Wednesday, falling even deeper – 1.26% - on Thursday morning. Big banks - Mitsubishi UFJ Financial, Mizuho Financial, and Sumitomo Financial – declined. Other companies - Sumitomo Chemical, Toshiba, Mitsumi Electric, Mitsubishi Motors, Mitsui OSK Lines, Nippon Yusen KK, and Pioneer – also finished in the red. Australian indices did better on Wednesday. The S&P/ASX rose 0.4%; the All Ordinaries jumped 0.3%. As was the case at the US market, energy stocks tumbled pushed down by falling oil prices. Origin Energy, Santos, and Beach Energy were firmly planted in the negative territory by the end of the trading day. Mining companies did worse than their counterparts in Europe and sank. BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group plummeted. The Shanghai Composite lost 0.7 %. The Hang Seng was 0.1% down on Wednesday but inched 0.86% higher on Thursday morning. The Indian Sensex rose 0.1%.

The US is giving August producer prices, retail sales, September Philadelphia Fed survey, and Empire Stat manufacturing survey. It is also reporting on August industrial production, July business inventories, weekly jobless claims, and Fed balance sheet and money supply.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: September 18, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_September_18_2016
video.description: Oil Prices Continued falling, hitting its one-month lows. The US dollar rose against all other currencies.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, US dollar, oil, gold.

content-body.text: Stocks dropped on Friday, 16 September 2016, pushed down by falling oil prices. Oil prices hit one-month low, trading at US$43.03, and negatively influenced energy companies. The Department of Justice advanced $14 billion claim against the Deutsche Bank. The Deutsche Bank slipped 8.47% and brought the financial sector lower. As the S&P 500 declined 0.4%, the dollar surged, reaching its highest level since July. The Bank of England’s monetary policy committee voted against changing its key interest rate. They also left asset purchase level unchanged. Rates are left at 0.25%. The Bank’s asset purchase ceiling remains at £435 billion. The Swiss National Bank also did not introduce any changes into its monetary policy. The key deposit rate remained as it was before, at minus 0.75%. The Swiss National Bank also said that it would continue interfering into the FX market with the aim of preventing the further growing of the Swiss franc. Retail sales data also failed to gladden investors. Retail sales lost 0.3% in August, which is more than everyone expected. August industrial production also declined 0.4%. Apart from indices in the Asia-Pacific region, other indices dipped. Dow Jones industrials shed 0.49%. The S&P 500 had a 0.38% slide. The NASDAQ edged 0.10% lower. The FTSE dropped 0.30%. The DAX tumbled 1.49%. The CAC lost 0.93%. The Asian stocks fared better. The Nikkei appreciated 0.70%. The Hang Seng closed 0.63% higher. The S&P/ASX rose 1.08%.

The US dollar reached its highest level since July. It advanced 0.8% against Euro. The Euro/USD pair was trading at 1.1155. The dollar remained virtually unchanged against the yen, trading at 102.31 yen. The dollar rose also against its other major counterparts. The ruble and the Mexican peso tumbled 0.3% and 2.2% respectively.

Crude declined 2%, trading at US43.03. For the week, it lost 6.2%. Copper prices reached the highest level in two months. Now it is trading at US$2.16. Zinc, which was the best performing metal of 2016, dipped for the first time this year. WTI Crude shed 0.88% to trade at US$43.03. Brent Crude was 0.88% lower to US$45.77. Gold spot lost 0.33% to US$1,310.35. Silver was 0.14% down to US$18.84. Platinum edged 1.14% lower to US$1,010.38.

US Market. Apple continued surging for the fourth day in a row, supported by the enthusiastic welcoming of his new iPhone. Hewlett-Packard Enterprise, an American multinational enterprise information technology company, jumped 0.59%. Global Payments slid 2.30%. Having promised to increase its dividend and to return $4 billion to shareholders, Goodyear Tire & Rubber moved into the positive territory. Because its late-stage trial of an experimental glaucoma drug was successful, Aerie Pharmaceuticals closed higher. AMC Networks dipped. In the wake of the scandal over opening of 2 million unauthorised accounts, Wells Fargo plummeted 1.56%. The Bank agreed to pay a $185 million in fine.

European Market. After it had signed a letter of intent to participate in €5 billion of energy, transportation, and infrastructure projects in Argentina, Siemens appreciated. Having announced its takeover of Monsanto, Bayer decreased 0.65%. EDF also closed in the red, losing 2.41%, even though the British government had given the green light to the construction of two EPR reactors. Zodiac Aerospace gained, as did Informa, after it had agreed to purchase Penton, an information service company, for £1.18 billion. Supermarkets in the UK did particularly well. Morrison supermarkets added 1.93%. Tesco was 0.02% higher. Sainsbury also ended 0.14% up. After reporting 0.5% decline in first-half profits, Next slid on Thursday, though it managed to rally on Friday.

Asia-Pacific Market. Investors were apprehensive of the Bank of Japan’s movements at the forthcoming meetings. Their worry and the rising yen sank the Nikkei that lost 1.3%. Banks were again down: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial, Mizuho Financial, and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial finished firmly in the negative territory. Nomura Holdings slid, and so did Daiwa Securities Group. Lawson advanced. In Australia, the S&P/ASX added 0.2%. The All Ordinaries gained as much. Mining companies did well. BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group soared. Because oil prices sank to their lowest level and because Libya had announced that it would increase its oil production, Woodside Petroleum, Origin Energy, and Santos retreated. The Hang Seng jumped 0.6%. The Sensex was also higher, edging 0.1% up.
The US is publishing August consumer price index along with September preliminary consumer sentiment. It is also giving report on July Treasury International capital.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: September 19, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_September_19_2016
video.description: Oil prices rose 2%, bringing stocks higher. The US dollar fell against all other currencies.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, US dollar, oil, gold.

content-body.text: Global stocks were mostly higher on Monday morning, 19 September 2016. Spirits at markets soared thanks to a sudden jump of oil prices. Oil rose overnight more than 2% after Venezuela said that oil producing countries, those that belong to OPEC and those that do not, are approaching an agreement about oil production and its output. What investors feared yesterday, namely Libya’s and Nigeria’s vigorous re-entry into the oil market, stopped looking frightening on Monday morning. Renewed conflicts in these regions eloquently show that the flow of oil from these countries would be prevented and is not going to rattle the economic world as drastically as everyone feared. Investors are also looking forward to the Bank of Japan’s policy meeting on Wednesday in hopes that it would substantially change its current monetary policy instead of pushing its rates further down the negative territory. Another event that fastened investors’ attention is the meeting of the Federal Reserve later this week. Although the meeting is eagerly awaited, not many people believe that the Federal Reserve policymakers are going to increase interest rates this time. The recent poll showed that economist estimate the probability of rates rise as one-in-four. Only 6% of economists expect the Federal Reserve to introduce changes. The majority of the people think that the Federal Reserve will wait with a rate hike until December, after the President Election has taken place. After losing badly last week, the majority of stocks climbed on Monday. The commodity-heavy FTSE added 1.27%. The French CAC was 1.30% higher. The DAX advanced 0.83%. Indices in the US also rallied. The Dow Jones Industrials appreciated 0.45%. The S&P 500 gained as much. The NASDAQ rose 0.47%. Asian indices did well, too, save the S&P/ASX that inched 0.04% lower. The Nikkei soared 0.70%. The Hang Seng was 0.90% higher.

The dollar lost on Monday on profit taking. It retreated against all of its counterparts. Its index was down 0.2%. The Australian dollar and Mexico’s peso were at the forefront of the currencies of oil exporting countries. The USD/JPY pair traded at 113.63. The Euro was 0.02% up and traded 1.1157 against the dollar.

Oil soared more than 2% on Monday. Precious metals surged as well. Gold was 0.49% up to reach US$1,316.77. Silver added 1.77% to US$19.20. Platinum gained 1.04% to US$1,026.76. WTI crude advanced 1.51% to US$43.68. Brent Crude was 0.555 higher to US$46.32. Copper was the only metal that lost on Monday. It traded at US$2.15.

US Market. Investors were pleasantly surprised by good August consumer price index. The CPI advanced 0.2%; the core soared 0.3%. This is more than everyone expected, previously foreseeing that the CPI would grow 0.1% and core would be 0.2% higher. After days of profits, Apple declined 0.56%. Oracle did too, shedding 4.75%. Intel bucked the losing trend jumping 3.04%. Despite an increase in oil prices, Chevron and Exxon Mobil declined. The former dropped 1.67%; the latter sank 1.23%. After the company chief executive said that Pratt & Whitney unit will not meet the expected target for deliveries of its new jet engine, United Technologies dipped 2.54%. W.W. Grainger, and industrial supply company, was also 4.26% low.

European Market. Energy stocks were pushed higher by growing oil prices. French oil and gas company, Total, appreciated 2.08%. The ENI also closed 2.72% higher. Its rival, Norwegian Statoil, added 1.36%. Miners in London ended the trading day firmly in the positive territory. Rio Tinto surged 2.81%. Glencore followed suit and gained 2.92%. BHP Billiton climbed 2.98%. Anglo American was 3.56% up. Financial stocks in Europe also fared well. Barclays soared 1.67%. Lloyds Banking Group edged 0.83% up. HSBC advanced 1.96%. The Royal Bank of Scotland appreciated 1.97%. Among these winners, only the Deutsche Bank and Capita declined. The former slid 1.00% threatened by the Department of Justice US$14 billion fine. Following the British Health Association’s criticism of its mistakes that are potentially damaging to clients’ health, Capita had a 1.03% slide.

Asia-Pacific Market. On Friday, markets in China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, South Korea, and Malaysia were closed in honour of the Mid-Autumn festival. Supplies of Apple did well and helped stocks climb. The Nikkei jumped 0.7%, even though investors refrained from making significant moves before the meeting of the Bank of Japan where it is expected to make its new monetary policy announcement. Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group soared 2.71%. Resona Holdings jumped 3.37%. Murata Manufacturing gained 4.22%. TDK advanced 3.98%. In Australia, both the S&P/ASX and the All Ordinaries rose 1.1% on Friday but slipped on the week 0.8%. On Monday morning, the S&P/ASX sank 0.04%. Indian stocks soared 0.7% on Friday but lost 0.7% for the week. Investors hope that the Reserve Bank of India will cut rates further/p>

On the 20th of September, the Bank of Japan is making its Monetary Policy announcement. The United States is making FOMC announcement and is reporting on August Housing Starts. Germany is giving its August Producer Price Index.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: September 21, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_September_21_2016
video.description: Oil prices rose 2.5%, bringing stocks higher, after the Bank of Japan announced its policy.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Bank of Japan, Binary Options trading, US dollar, oil, gold.

content-body.text: Global stocks were high on Wednesday morning after the Bank of Japan’s monetary policy had been announced. Despite prognosis, the Bank of Japan decided not to enter further into negative territory. Instead, it shifted the focus of its stimulus to controlling the yield curve. Banks and insuring companies soared supported by the Bank of Japan’s monetary policy. Oil also surged, trading today more than US$45 per barrel. The yen slipped 0.1% but managed to pare its losses slightly afterwards. All indices advanced. The Dow Jones industrials added 0.05%. The S&P were 0.03% higher. The NASDAQ rose 0.12%. The FTSE in the UK appreciated 0.42%. The DAX gained 0.91%. The French CAC closed 0.99% higher. The Nikkei increased 1.91%. The Hang Seng climbed 0.59%. The S&P/ASX was 0.68% up.

The US dollar was at its seven weeks high. The yen slid 0.1%. The pound was in the weakest position among currencies, dropping 0.5%. After Czech state secretary for EU Affairs said that the UK will not have both immigration restriction and free market access. The pound traded at US$1.2967. Euro is down slightly. Commodity sensitive, the Canadian and Australian dollars rose.

Crude oil was up 2.5%. It traded on Wednesday morning at 45.14%. Oil jumped because Algeria energy minister said OPEC may make its informal meeting formal. From his statement, everyone concluded that major oil producers will decide to limit oil output. Precious metals continued rising. Gold advanced 0.35% to US$1,319.38. Silver was 1.13% higher to US$19.50. Platinum jumped 0.88% higher to trade at 1,039.01. Copper slipped 0.35% to reach at US$2.15. Brent Crude gained 1.79% to US$46.70.

US market. Having completed a $5 billion debt offering, Gilead Sciences that makes a hepatitis C drug rose 3.53%. Merck pharmaceuticals advanced 0.99%. Ascena Retail Group lost whooping 29.93%, hitting a seven years low. Ascena Retail Group’s had reported weak quarterly results and disappointing forecast. Allergan is about to purchase Tobira Therapeutics that works on liver disease drug, paying for it $1.47 billion. Tobira appreciated unbelievable 720.89%. Allergan slightly dipped 0.51%.

European market. Having closed the deal about the takeover of Monsanto, Bayer continued climbing. Deutsche Bank, still threatened by US$14 billion fine, lost on Tuesday afternoon, though it managed to add 0.12% on Wednesday morning. Commerzbank was 3.38% up. Renault gained 2.08%. Because oil was higher, energy stocks advanced. Technip appreciated 0.23%. Total edged 0.66% higher. Tullow Oil surged 1.56%.

Asia-Pacific market. After the Bank of Japan announced its monetary policy, cheering investors up that it did not go deeper into negative territory with its interest rates, and after bank and insurers jumped, Japan’s Topix index added 2.7%. The Nikkei was slightly lower than Topix, rising 1.91%. The Hang Seng advanced 0.59%. After the worst outrage on Monday, the Australian markets gained. The S&P/ASX rallied 0.68% on Wednesday morning.
The Federal Reserve is announcing it monetary policy. Japan is posting August merchandise trade balance. The UK is giving a report on august public sector finances.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: September 22, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_September_22_2016
video.description: The Federal Reserve left rates unchanged. Stocks jumped, while the US dollar slid.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Federal Reserve, interest rates, US dollar, oil, gold.

content-body.text: Wednesday, 21 September 2016, was an eagerly expected day and it brought news satisfying everyone’s expectations. As economists anticipated, the Federal Reserve did not rise rates. However much it praised the blossoming state of the economy, the Federal Reserve decided to wait for more signs of its strengthening, putting off a rates hike until December or, possibly, until the beginning of the next year. Whether the end of 2016 becomes the right time for rates increase will depend on how the economy, inflation, and markets fare before the presidential election in December. Meanwhile, rates range remains at 0.25% to 0.50%. The vote by FOMC members was 6 to 3. The Federal Reserve’s insistence on the same level of rates gave markets a substantial boost. All indices, without exception, advanced on Wednesday and remained in positive territory on Thursday morning. The Dow Jones industrials climbed 0.90%. The S&P 500 was 1.09% higher. The NASDAQ appreciated 1.03%. The FTSE in the UK edged 0.40% up. The French CAC gained 0.89%. The DAX in Germany advanced 0.95%. The Asian stocks did particularly well, supported by energy companies and raw-materials producers. The Hang Seng rose 0.43%. The Australian S&P/ASX increased 0.65%. The Japanese markets were closed for holiday. The US dollar plummeted against most of other major currencies. The won climbed.

The dollar retreated against all but two of its major counterparts. The yen remained unchanged on Thursday morning after palpable vacillations on Wednesday. It traded at 100.47 against the dollar. The Euro/USD pair was trading at US$1.1233. The Australian dollar increased 0.3%. The worst performer among major currencies was the New Zealand’s currency. The British pound slightly advanced, trading at 1.3069 against the dollar.

Oil prices went up on optimism that the solution for oil oversupply could be found in Algeria. On Thursday morning crude oil traded at $45.77 per barrel. Adding to everyone’s good feelings about OPEC members’ meeting on September 28, Saudi Arabia and Iran discussed the problem with oil glut in Vienna a week before the organisation’s informal meeting takes place in Algeria. The decline of the American dollar caused the prices of precious and industrial metals to climb. Copper, lead, and aluminium advanced at least 0.8%. Copper reached US$2.15 Brent Crude added 0.92% to trade at US$46.70. Gold was higher at US$1,333.63. Silver rose 0.34% to US$19.80. Platinum traded at US$1,048.30, though it slipped slightly later during the day.

US Market. After it improved its forecast for the year and demonstrated excellent third-quarter results, Adobe Systems, an American multinational computer software company, gained 7.21%. FedEx boasted unexpectedly good first quarter results, increased its yearly forecast, and also advanced, jumping 6.89%. Having posted good results, KB Home rose 2.01%. Because there were discussions of the rising price of Mylan’s allergy shot EpiPen, many drug companies declined, again negatively affected by controversies over prices of the medicine they make. Amgen slid, and so did Alexion that dropped 1.04%. Walgreens Boots lost 0.07%. CVS Heath Corporation followed suit and fell 0.27%, though it managed to pare its losses on Thursday morning. Hit by poor sales, CarMax dipped 2.04%. Intending to purchase $5 billion in company stocks, Target rallied 1.19%. Microsoft also promised to buy back $40 billion in stock, Microsoft added 1.67%.

European Market. New monetary policy advanced on Wednesday by the Bank of Japan and the Federal Reserve’s decision to leave its interest rates unchanged brought banks and other financial stocks up. Barclays, Standard Chartered, Lloyds Banking Group, and HSBC were firmly in positive territory by the end of the trading session. Commerzbank, BNP Paribas, Société Générale, and Crédit Agricole also finished in the green. Insurance companies rose for the same reason. Evotec climbed 1.52%. Having signed a deal about five-year partnership researching kidney disease, Bayer was 0.48% higher. After it said it would sell its bonds, Ubisoft, a company that makes video games, retreated in Paris. BHP Billiton gained 2.70% in London. Diageo, a British multinational alcoholic beverages company, soared 1.35%. Zurich Insurance Group announced that it would combine its corporate and commercial businesses and surged 0.95% on Thursday morning.

Asia-Pacific Market. Japanese Markets were closed for holidays. Other Asian markets surged. An MSCI index of shares extended gains for the six day. The Shanghai Composite advanced 0.1%. The Hang Seng jumped 0.43% on Thursday morning. Nine Dragons Paper Holdings, a privately owned paper manufacturing company in Mainland China, added 7.71%. Hanjin Shipping, South Korea’s largest container carrier, rose whooping 29.61%. Korean airlines were also up, jumping 5.43%. As was the case in Europe, banks moved into positive territory. Because the yen eased a bit during last few days, exporters appreciated. Honda Motor, Mazda, Panasonic, and Sharp reaped profits. Having received takeover offers, Takata, a Japanese automotive parts company, slid 1.60%. In Australia, the S&P/ASX was 0.65% higher. The All Ordinaries were also in the green. Australian banks fared as well as other banks around the world did on Wednesday and early Thursday. Positively influenced by the Bank of Japan’s new monetary policy, NAB, ANZ, and Westpac peaked. Rio Tinto gained 3.25%. The Kospi closed 0.5% higher on Wednesday. The Indian Sensex declined 0.1%.

September flash EC consumer confidence is going to be announced. The US is giving August existing home sales and leading indicators. FHFA house price index for July is also going to be revealed. In addition, weekly jobless claims, money supply, and Fed balance sheet are going to be published today.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: September 26, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_September_26_2016
video.description: Oil jumped on speculations that Saudi Arabia would cut its production to January levels. Gold dipped 0.2%. Stocks declined, with Asian stocks doing the worst.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Saudi Arabia’s oil glut solutions, US dollar, oil, gold.

content-body.text: Oil remains the major topic for discussion among economists. Its fluctuating prices influence investors’ mood and performance of stocks. On Monday morning, 26 September 2016, oil prices jumped but failed either to gladden investors or bring stocks higher. The reason for the advancement of oil prices stemmed from Saudi Arabia’s offer to cut oil production to January levels so that other countries could follow suit and, thereby, jointly achieve the resolution of the problem with oil glut. Although everyone’s immediate reaction to Saudi Arabia’s plan was renewed optimism over the solution of oil oversupply, reflected in the oil price, which climbed to US$44.84 on Monday morning, investors still understand that Saudi Arabia again might simply be trying to talk oil prices up to its advantage. They also suspect that the Saudis’ recent manoeuvre to advise Iran to curb its oil production in exchange for Saudi Arabia’s agreement to freeze its own is only an attempt to blame the Iranians for the lack of deal afterwards. After they have put blame at the door of the Persians, the Saudis will be able to propose conditions that would suit them the most. Investors are sceptical about the resolution of the problem with oil surplus also because oil is being produced now with increased zeal. More than 800,000 extra barrels per day are being delivered to the global market. Russia started to produce more oil; Libya and Nigeria are also restoring supply earlier disrupted by fighting in their regions. Despite earlier forecasts that oil oversupply would be reduced in 2016, it will most probably continue being a pressing problem throughout 2017. With these gloomy conclusions on their minds, investors were not cheered up by today’s oil jump. Global stocks were deploringly down in the morning on Monday. Apart from the S&P/ASX that was flat in Australia, other indices dipped, with the Hang Seng leading losses. The Dow Jones sank 0.71%; the S&P 500 shed 0.57%; the NASDAQ declined 0.63%; the FTSE in the UK slipped 0.81%; the DAX dropped 0.92%; the CAC in France decreased 1.10%. Asian stocks tumbled by the most in two weeks, sharing the lowest position with the Indian Sensex. The Hang Seng lost 1.53%. Because the yen added 0.2% on Monday, the Nikkei declined 1.25%.

The US dollar advanced versus most of its major counterparts save the euro and the Canadian dollar. Its index remained unchanged after it lost 0.6% last week. The yen advanced 0.2% to trade at 100.87 per dollar. The pound continued being lower, pulled down by Boris Johnson’s promise of the UK’s swift exit from the European Union. The GBP/USD pair was 1.2951 on Monday. The Euro was 1.1236 per dollar. The lira dropped to a seven-week low against the dollar, after Moody had cut Turkey’s sovereign rating to Ba1 on Friday. The Philippine peso sank to a seven-year low, because foreign investors, disenchanted by the president’s policies, had started to take away their capital from the country.

Crude Oil soared to US44.77. Brent Crude rose 0.70% trading at $46.21. Prices of precious metals swing the most lately, variously affected by the US forthcoming presidential elections and an always expected rates hike by the Federal Reserve. Even though gold advanced 2.1% last week, it slid 0.2% on Monday morning, trading at US$1,335.76. Platinum was also lower. It lost 0.79% to reach US$1,045.65. Silver was 0.88% down to US$19.64. Copper slid 0.39% and traded at US$2.19 in the morning on Monday.

US Market. Because its President and Chief Executive Officer is about to resign, Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, a publishing house for educational online and CD-ROM products, declined whooping 10.95%. Having reported good sales and earnings in second quarter, Finish Line, an athletic footwear and apparel retailer, dropped 5.17%, nevertheless. Twitter was up 21.42% for the second day in a row nearing the takeover negotiations. Thanks to mendacious reports about the length of time its customers spend on watching video ads, Facebook fell 1.63% again, making investors think that its revenue is endangered. Because the data of its 500 million users had been stolen by a foreign agent, Yahoo retreated 3.06%. With a new chief executive announced, Endo International advanced 0.30%. Apple was still 1.67% down affected by conclusions that its new iPhone 7 will not be popular in Europe.

European Markets. European companies were mostly in the red. E.ON promised to pay its customers £3.1 million for missed appointments, for which it had never paid its customers. The company’s shares, therefore, slumbered 1.29%. RWE sank 1.63%. European banks were firmly planted in negative territory. Deutsche Bank, Commerzbank, Société Générale, BNP Paribas, Crédit Agricole, Royal Bank of Scotland, Standard Chartered, and Lloyds Banking Group slipped. Total lost 1.97%. Techip was also down, shedding 2.01%. Polymetal dropped 2.65%. After many US states filed a complaint against the company’s violation of state and federal laws, Indivior retreated 0.70%.
